title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — On a night when defense was supposed to reign, one man authored an offensive masterpiece for the ages.

Gary Payton, the Seattle SuperSonics’ relentless floor general, delivered a historic performance, pouring in a game-high 42 points to single-handedly will his team to a 99-93 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Payton’s night. The Pacers, a formidable defensive squad, had no answer for “The Glove’s” complete arsenal. He sliced through the lane for acrobatic finishes, pulled up with unwavering confidence from mid-range, and orchestrated the entire Sonics offense with a commanding presence. His 42 points were not just a number; they were a statement, a relentless assault that broke the will of a proud Indiana team.

While Payton’s scoring barrage dominated, he was not alone. Detlef Schrempf provided crucial support with 19 points against his former team, and Vin Baker added a steady 16. But this night belonged unequivocally to Payton.

Indiana fought valiantly, led by Reggie Miller’s 22 points and a strong 18-point, 11-rebound double-double from Rik Smits. Yet, every time the Pacers mounted a challenge, it was Payton who answered with a cold-blooded jumper or a drive into the heart of the defense, snuffing out any hope of an Indiana comeback.

In the final moments, as the Seattle SuperSonics secured the hard-fought road win, all eyes were on the man who had authored one of the season’s most iconic individual performances. Gary Payton didn’t just win a game; he staged a one-man clinic, leaving no doubt about whose night it was in Indianapolis.
